related_questions.question: Why would a cardiologist order a heart catheterization?
related_questions.snippet: This procedure is most often done to get information about the heart or its blood vessels. It may also be done to treat some types of heart conditions, or to find out if you need heart surgery. Your doctor may perform cardiac catheterization to diagnose or evaluate: Causes of congestive heart failure or cardiomyopathy.
related_questions.title: Cardiac catheterization Information | Mount Sinai - New York

related_questions.question: What is the most common condition that necessitates cardiac catheterization?
related_questions.title: You might need cardiac catheterization if you have, or your doctor thinks you have:
list: Damage to the walls and inner lining of tiny blood vessels in the heart, called small vessel disease or coronary microvascular disease.

related_questions.question: Can heart catheterization clear a blockage?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Diagnostic Tool: Cardiac catheterization is primarily a diagnostic tool used to visualize the heart's arteries and identify any blockages or other problems.
Treatment Option: If a blockage is detected, the procedure can be expanded to treat it. This is done by inserting a catheter with a balloon and/or stent.
Angioplasty: The balloon is inflated to expand the narrowed artery, pushing the blockage outwards.
Stenting: A small mesh tube (stent) is then deployed to keep the artery open.
Medication-Coated Stents: Some stents may be coated with medication to help prevent the artery from becoming blocked again.
Alternative to Bypass Surgery: Cardiac catheterization and angioplasty/stenting can be a less invasive alternative to open-heart surgery like coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).
Transradial Approach: In some cases, the catheter can be inserted through a blood vessel in the wrist (transradial cardiac catheterization) according to Johns Hopkins Medicine.

related_questions.question: What symptoms require a heart cath?
related_questions.title: You may have a cardiac cath if you have recently had 1 or more of these symptoms:

text_blocks.snippet: A heart catheterization, also known as a coronary angiogram, is a medical procedure that allows doctors to visualize and assess the heart and its blood vessels.

list.snippet: Coronary artery disease: Blockages or narrowed arteries that supply blood to the heart.
Heart valve problems: Leaky, narrowed, or damaged valves that regulate blood flow through the heart.
Heart muscle function: How well the heart pumps blood.
Blood pressure in the heart chambers: Pressures in the different chambers of the heart.
Blood flow: The amount and speed of blood flowing through the heart and its vessels.
Congenital heart defects: Abnormalities in the structure of the heart present since birth.
Tumors or other growths: Abnormal masses in or around the heart.
A heart catheterization can also be used to perform certain treatments, such as stenting (inserting a small tube to open up blocked arteries) or valve repair.
The procedure typically takes about 30-60 minutes.
Images from the catheterization are displayed on a monitor, allowing the doctor to analyze the heart in real time.
The results of the catheterization can help doctors diagnose heart conditions, determine the best treatment options, and monitor the progress of heart disease.
